issues.title: New IANA registries are contrary to the main spec IANA section
issues.author: rohan-wire
issues.body:
The extensions draft IANA section begins:

> This document requests the creation of the following new IANA registries:
>
>* MLS Extension Types ({{extended-mls-extension-types}})
>* MLS Proposal Types ({{extended-mls-proposal-types}})

This is contradictory to the clear language in the IANA considerations of the MLS protocol spec (example quoted from Section 17.2):

>[17.2. ](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mls-protocol-16.html#section-17.2)[MLS Extension Types](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mls-protocol-16.html#name-mls-extension-types)
>
>This registry lists identifiers for extensions to the MLS protocol. The extension type field is two bytes wide, so valid extension type values are in the range 0x0000 to 0xffff.

New extensions are supposed to be added to the **_EXISTING_** IANA registries.

comments.author: rohan-wire
comments.body: Submitted PR #4 to fix.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body: Closed via #4.

issues.title: Add wire format capability negotiation extension
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
A notable omission from the Capabilities / RequiredCapabilities objects in RFC 9420 is the ability to negotiate support for new wire formats.  This document should address that deficiency.  What we would need is a `supported_wire_formats` extension, where:

* The content of the extension is `WireFormat wire_formats<V>;`
* The extension can appear in LeafNode and GroupContextExtensions
* The semantic in LeafNode is "here are the new WireFormats I support"
* The semantic in GroupContextExtensions is "here are the WireFormats that are required for this group"

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body:
Not covered by the current appsync, but this should just be a short extension/section in the document.

Would also be great if we could add this to content type.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body: Closed via #43.

issues.title: Streamline Safe Extensions section
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
The Safe Extensions section currently has a bunch of unnecessary baggage, which we should rearrange and/or delete.

The core of what Safe Extensions needs to define is: What does an extension need to do in order to be considered a safe extension?

From that perspective, the sections on HPKE, signatures, export, and PSKs all make sense, in the sense that an extension is safe if the only HPKE/signature/export/PSKs mechanisms uses are the ones defined here.  That leaves the "Security", "Extension Designer Tools", and "Extension Design Guidance" sections.

* "Security" should just be the introduction to the Safe Extensions section.
* "Extension Designer Tools" should be deleted.  The mechanisms here abuse the extension types for labelling things other than extensions, and they don't really provide any value over the base extensibility mechanisms they use.  At best, they provide "ignorable" objects of the various types, which is a totally different property than Safe Extensions provides.
* "Extension Design Guidance" is not specific to Safe Extensions.  It should be promoted to its own top-level section.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
I agree with your points 1 and 3. Point 3 is (I believe) already covered by Rohan's #31.

On Point 2: I partially agree in that this section should live outside of Section 2, because it's useful for both safe and unsafe extensions. I don't think it should be removed, though. The purpose of these additional structs is to allow extensions authors to just request an extension code point, after which they can create any proposal/credential or WireFormat they like without requiring additional code points. It also makes negotiation simpler, as support for an extension always implies support for all proposals, etc. associated by that extension. If anything, this mechanisms improve the base extensibility mechanisms we have in MLS.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Will be addressed with refactoring PR.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: I believe this is now addressed in #43

comments.body:
Indeed the text is less confusing now, thanks!

Still, I am wondering: it seems to be that MLS clients deal primarily with `FramedContent`, and MLS implementations translate them to `PublicMessage` or `PrivateMessage`, which are more like internal structures? If this is true, I would have framed it as "An MLS FramedContent can contain [...]" instead of "An MLS PrivateMessage can contain [...]", but this is mostly nit-picking so I guess we can close.

comments.body:
Sorry, I guess I just think of it as the first A in AAD. All the data in a PublicMessage is authenticated data. It doesn't have any different properties in the authenticated_data field than it would elsewhere in the message (in application_data for example).
By "no place to put it" I just meant that there is no AEAD algorithm we are putting the **_A_** AD into.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body:
The current text is

```
An MLS PrivateMessage can contain arbitrary additional application-specific AAD. The corresponding authenticated_data field appears in several MLS structs: FramedContent (used indirectly to generate the message signature and tags), PrivateContentAAD (used as the AAD input to the PrivateMessage.ciphertext), and PrivateMessage (to convey the AAD).
```

I agree with @TWal that it sounds confusing. The AAD in question appears in two places: the `authenticated_data` field of `PrivateMessage` and `PublicMessage`. `FramedContent` and `PrivateContentAAD` are helper structs for both the spec and implementations. 
The text should be changed accordingly.

issues.title: `SafeEncryptWithContext` should use `EncryptWithLabel`
issues.author: TWal
issues.body:
MLS defines the safe-ish `SignWithLabel`, `ExpandWithLabel`, `EncryptWithLabel` etc, and the safe API relies on it:
- `SafeSignWithLabel` uses `SignWithLabel`
- `DeriveExtensionSecret` uses `ExpandWithLabel`

However `SafeEncryptWithContext` doesn't use `EncryptWithLabel` and operate directly with `HPKE.SealBase`. Is there a technical reason for this?

I think it should use `EncryptWithLabel` to ensure proper domain separation with HPKE uses in the MLS RFC. Otherwise, we must ensure that MLS' `EncryptContext` and Safe API's `LabeledExtensionContent` cannot be serialized to the same bytestring (to follow the secure formatting rules of the [Comparse paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2023/1390)). The latter fact seems to hold, under the condition that `LabeledExtensionContent.label` uses a QUIC-style length encoding (which is not clear because it is written as `opaque label` and not `opaque label<V>`). Using `EncryptWithLabel` would make that fact straightforward.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body: We use `EncryptWithLabel` now.

issues.title: SelfRemove: Extension and Proposal?
issues.author: kkohbrok
issues.body:
The text describing SelfRemove mentions a SelfRemove extension and a SelfRemove proposal in different places, but while the SelfRemove proposal is defined (as an empty struct) and mentioned in the IANA considerations, the extension is not. The first question is thus: Is there meant to be an extension?

TL;DR: No, I think we should just remove mentions of an extension and stick with the proposal only. (See #68)

The second question is whether the needs to be an extension. On one hand Section [12.4.3.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9420.html#section-12.4.3.2) of RFC9420 says that an external commit MUST NOT contain proposals by reference, so the use of SelfRemove proposals effectively needs to change the protocol. On the other hand Section [12.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9420.html#section-12.2) says that new proposals definitions can update the validation logic.

While the MUST NOT in Section 12.4.3.2 is technically not covered by the exception made for new proposal definitions in 12.2, I think it's totally fine for new proposals to define whether they're allowed in external commits by reference. Clients need to signal support for the proposal anyway, so there shouldn't be a problem with interop here and groups that don't want to allow SelfRemoves because they can't be validated fully in external commits can just forbid them by policy.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: PTAL at this issue and PR. We would like to decide whether to merge or close the PR by July 18th. Please see this [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/mls/iE7LcClGOXzQKWaTRfc54TBPpCI/).

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Agreed that we should merge #68 and close this issue. SelfRemove is a proposal type.

issues.title: Is Component Type (ComponentID) a u16 or u32?
issues.author: kkohbrok
issues.body:
[Section 4.4.](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mls-extensions-08.html#section-4.4) says ComponentID is a u16, while the IANA table lists values in the range of a u32. 

One notable consequence of which we go for is the size of the PPRF described in Section 4.4. If we go with a u16, the PPRF has 2^16 leaves, which means that after one query, it has a size of ~650kB (16 nodes in a path with 32 bytes plus an index for each node). Following queries add first 15 nodes, then 14, etc, roughly doubling the size each time. If we go with a u32, the size roughly doubles, starting from ~1,3kB after the first query, then again almost doubling with each subsequent one.

I don't have a strong opinion here, just wanted to note that it's a little inconsistent and that the choice comes with a slight trade-off in group state size.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: It is currently a u32, but I'd be happy to make it a u16.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body:
> It is currently a u32, but I'd be happy to make it a u16.

Sounds reasonable. Do you want to open a PR?

issues.title: Cross-layer support
issues.author: xisentian
issues.body: The current scoping of the extensions document restricts content advertisement to support only the application layer - specifically particular media types. The MLS Application is defined within this document as "the system that instantiates, manages, and uses an MLS group" which implies if other protocol layers used MLS, then they should be able to utilize the Safe Application Interface to agree on layer-specific content. Thus, components within Safe API should be generalized further to support protocol layers other than application.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Xisen, could you elaborate on some examples of content that could not be represented using media types? Or is the issue that it would be clumsy to represent the supported types of content?

comments.author: xisentian
comments.body: @rohanmahy, the structure of the media types is sufficient, in my opinion, for the content we were _originally_ thinking of: group supported application protocols, transport layer parameters, server name indication.To your other point though, it does seem clumsy to represent them under media-types which is why I proposed to represent the content in their own categorized base-layer types. This expansion of the base-label accommodates other TCP/IP layers that may want to utilize MLS group context agreement (i.e. cross layer support).

issues.title: App data dictionary in GroupContext
issues.author: franziskuskiefer
issues.body:
Putting a lot of data into an app data dictionary in the group context, in order to ensure everyone agrees on it, has a negative impact on performance. Not only on the size of the `Welcome` message, but on the performance of computing messages and commits. The group context is part of the `FramedContentTBS`, key schedule, and the path secret encryption.

The text on Sec 4.7 currently [suggests](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-mls-extensions#section-4.7-10.1.1) that requiring the application to handle the application state is not what we want in the draft. But I think it needs more guidance on how this should be used. This is primarily an issue for the group context extension. Putting a lot of data into the extension in other cases does not hurt MLS performance as much.

**Suggestion**

Provide some more guidance on usage of app data dictionary such as
- Only small app data dictionaries should be put into the group context.
- Large amounts of app data should be stored outside of the group context and linked back only with a commitment (hash).

Define an additional way of storing app data in the group context that performs the hashing with the hash from the ciphersuite, to avoid putting this burden onto the application.

comments.author: rohanmahy
franziskuskiefer
comments.body:
> The GroupContext is only included on signatures of external commits right?

No, it's members and external commits (select cases fall through).

For OpenMLS the numbers look as follows. OpenMLS currently doesn't optimise anything here. So this could be better if some values would be cached. But not all values can be cached.

bytes | ms
-- | --
128 | 0.492167
512 | 0.447209
1024 | 0.454916
10240 | 1.526167
102400 | 7.1805

> In terms of concrete action

Yes, I think in this document we should at least add text about the negative impact and advice to using hashes for larger blobs.

I'm not sure what this document should say about storing of the values outside of the group context and linking it into the group only with a digest. I agree with the text in the document right now that this adds significant complexity onto the application.

But I think we could integrate the option of storing only the hashed app data dictionary in the group context into this document with very little text. Right now the `AppDataUpdate` proposal is interpreted by the application already. The [processing step](https://messaginglayersecurity.rocks/mls-extensions/draft-ietf-mls-extensions.html#section-4.7-9.2.2.2.1) ("The application logic returns either an opaque value new_data that will be stored as the new application data for this component, or else an indication that it considers this update invalid.") could be updated to allow setting a flag to hash the value instead of storing it.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body:
@franziskuskiefer @rohanmahy Can you please sync on this and propose a PR?
Also, does this relate to `draft-mahy-mls-new-framed-content-tbs`?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> [@franziskuskiefer](https://github.com/franziskuskiefer) [@rohanmahy](https://github.com/rohanmahy) Can you please sync on this and propose a PR? Also, does this relate to `draft-mahy-mls-new-framed-content-tbs`?

The draft above is an attempt to improve performance generating and verifying MLS messages in general, especially as the GC gets large.

comments.body: I'll suggest some wording here that I think could work.

issues.title: AppDataUpdate granularity
issues.author: kkohbrok

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body: Thanks @kkohbrok . To be clear, the way I interpreted the draft is the app_data_dictionary is a collection of entries organized by Component ID, and the AppDataUpdate is a way to replace or remove the complete entry associated with an individual Component ID instead of having to send the entire dictionary collection over the wire. Is that correct, or is there a finer level of granularity intended (i.e. sub-entries within the entry)

comments.author: keks
comments.body:
@bitbltr That is not how I read it. From [4.7](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mls-extensions-08.html#section-4.7-9.2.1):

> If the list comprises one or more proposals, all with op field set to update:
> - Provide the application logic registered to the `component_id` value with the content of the update field from each proposal, in the order specified.
> - The application logic returns either an opaque value `new_data` that will be stored as the new application data for this component, or else an indication that it considers this update invalid.
> - ...

According to the text, `new_data` is returned by the application logic, and I don't see any indication that is the same as the content of the update field.

The application data could replace the entry verbatim, have some "sub-entry" logic or implement a diff/patch/CRDT algorithm. It's not specified.

comments.author: bitbltr
keks
comments.body: This already is a problem for core protocol functionality like adding new members to a group. The application defines the policies, and all clients must agree on these (not just in spirit, but also in implementation behaviour). If they don't, the group state may fork. To me, this is just an extension of that.

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body: I think it's a much bigger problem than the one you describe regarding adding members to a group. It's one thing to agree on policy, it's another thing to allow the context to get out of sync because some vendor adds a new component ID. I think this is a huge hole in the proposal with far reaching implications and should be implemented as an opaque update.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
My understanding was that if you want to be able to use a component in the group contect (i.e. update it via proposal), the group must require support that component via entry in the `app_components` entry in the `app_data_dictionary`.

Granted, that's not stated in the document currently, but I think it should be. I don't think it's a good idea to have components on the GroupContext level that are not supported by every group member.

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body:
@kkohbrok If it were specified somewhere that all required Component IDs must be enumerated in order to join the group, then that would make sense. But I still see caveats:

1. The space is 2^32. That is potentially a huge number of Component IDs to enumerate
2. Half the ID space is reserved for private vendor use (0x80000000 - 0xFFFFFFFF). Perhaps the vendor has custom logic only for their clients and there is no way for another vendor's clients to support those IDs. Now the group can never converge.

I keep circling back to opaque updates is the way to go.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
I don't understand the concern about the space of component IDs. Do you expect that such a large number of component IDs will be in use that they bloat the group context? If a vendor has custom logic that's fine, but that means that logic can't be used when interoperating with other clients. Specifically, such an ID should only be used in the `app_data_dictionary` if all clients are from the same vendor.

I'm still having trouble imagining where we run into trouble when we use non-opaque app-controlled updates to `app_data_dictionary`. Can you maybe sketch a concrete scenario that you expect to be relevant in practice?

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body:
I think what it really comes down to is are there only required components or can there be optional components. If there is such a thing as optional components, then the group needs to be able to process group context updates without understanding the content of the app data entries for the optional components.

But if the intention is all clients must support a list of components and there are no optional components, then your technique is valid.

I don't like this result however. From my experience designing APIs, I think you're ensuring vendor fragmentation and non-interoperable clients especially because of the space reserved for private vendor use. It would be different if only IETF-approved components were allowed.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: The contents of `update` are defined by each component. It could be a complete replacement (as in [MIMI room metadata](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mimi-protocol-05.html#name-room-metadata)) or a patch (as in [MIMI participant lists](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-mimi-protocol-05.html#name-participant-list)).

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body:
@rohanmahy Thank you for clarification. However if that is the intent, then clients can only join sessions that have Component IDs they understand, otherwise they will not be able to keep the group state synchronized (because they do not have the application logic to handle patches). So there needs to be an advertisement as to what Component IDs are required by the group context (in addition to the AppDataUpdate proposal type in the proposal_types list in the group's required_capabilities extension). That way the client can effectively say "I don't understand that Component ID, so therefore I cannot join."

Personally, I think this design is fatally flawed for future compatibility, especially since vendors can add their own Component IDs.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body: You're right that vendors can add their own component IDs and they can use them within groups where all clients support those IDs. Note that they can always use those IDs in leaf nodes components regardless of other client support. Is there a concrete use case where a vendor might want to store some data in the group context of a group where not all clients actually know what the data in that group context is?

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body:
I think the language in the draft is insufficient. The leaves can declare what component IDs they support, but the group context decides the *only* component IDs that can be used. They're not just required, they are exclusive to all other component IDs. So perhaps something more like "When present in a LeafNode, the semantic is the list of supported components. When present in the GroupContext, the semantic is the list of components that are required and no other components may be used." That way, there is no concept of optional components in the GC.

While that may clarify the current thinking, I still believe this will render vendor extensibility useless. It is unreasonable to expect that every client can support every vendor extension. It would be like forcing Gmail and Outlook to support the same features. Or more likely, a vendor releases a component, but no other client has had time to implement the app logic for it, so now they can't join the group.

It doesn't matter the specific use case. The fact that the mechanism exists at all means that clients will get out of sync and only the vendors with the most resources to keep up with random vendor extensions will be able to move forward. No developer can anticipate supporting app logic from every other developer around the world for the lifetime of their product.

I think a better mechanism would be components listed as required by the GC will support opaque and patch updates. Optional components outside of the required components can be used, but they must be opaque updates. That way all clients can at least join the group and maintain the GC state.

comments.author: bitbltr
comments.body: Taking it even further, it could be used nefariously. Say a few years from now, the largest client vendor creates a component and does not publish the application logic to support it, but now requires it for any MLS group they create. They've effectively locked out every other client from participating.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Hi,
you didn't understand the semantics. they are the same as extension_types.
There is a list called app_components. When present in the GroupContext, it
indicates which conponents must be understood by every member of the group.
The components may or may not be actually present in the data dictionary in
the Group context.

Unknown components can safely appear in LeafNodes, KeyPackages, GroupInfo,
application messages, AppEphemeral proposals, and AAD without harm, but
GroupContext is key to the agreement of MLS. This mirrors the handling of
extensions in MLS, so the semantics are not new. Every member needs to
understand the GroupContext.

If you want the semantics that any member can put anything they want in
another container, feel free to propose a new MLS GroupContext extension
called opaque_dictionary. I don't see value for some members keeping state
in the GroupContext that other members don't understand, but maybe others
will.

reviews.author: franziskuskiefer
reviews.body:
Some first comments.
The general approach looks fine. But I'm a little worried about the way the encryption and authentication work together. Maybe you can work out a little better what the security (confidentiality and authentication) guarantees should be for targeted messages (also compared to regular MLS application messages). They are not entirely clear to me.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This extensions introduces a new message type to the MLS protocol,
```
It's worth noting that the signature/hpke scheme is the same as the one defined in the MLS ciphersuite of the group. I could imagine using a different mechanism for the signature here for example.
So this is only needed when using signatures, right?
Why not allow `mode_auth`?

Is the idea that the PSK binds the message to an epoch? The security properties are a little unclear because the HPKE key is a relatively long-lived key but this one is not.
Reading further it looks like you really want to use PSK (encryption) and want use HPKE/Signature (authentication) only for authentication? This doesn't become clear from the text. I thought you were doing HPKE (encryption) + hpke_auth/signature (authentication). But then the encryption is always HPKE (not PSK), which makes me very confused.
Using `HPKEAuth` when it is actually `HPKEAuthPsk` is a little confusing.
You should mention somewhere that `SealAuthPSK` etc. are from RFC 9180.

reviews.author: raphaelrobert
reviews.body: Thanks for the review, I hope my comments clarify things.

comments.body:
We could drop the PSK part, but that would be unnecessarily weak because all security guarantees would only depend on the HPKE keys. Using the PSK gives us a pretty efficient way to couple targeted messages with the key schedule of the base protocol to achieve the following guarantees:

 - FS & PCS that we have between epochs
 - Better confidentiality, meaning a passive attacker must compromise the group state as well, not just the HPKE key
 - Proof of membership, meaning an active attacker must compromise the group state as well, not just the HPKE key

So in other words, we always use HPKE + PSK for encryption. For authentication, we always use PSK, and additionally either HPKEAuth or signatures. The latter is really either `mode_auth_psk` or `mode_psk + Signature`.
See the comment below.
That's correct
Good point.
I see how that's confusing. I left out the PSK part because it is common to both authentication modes and therefore not a differentiator. I'll try to think of a better name.
Good point.

I'm all for using PSK here 🙂 
My main point is that it needs to become clear where the security is coming from and how the different things work together.
The PSK in HPKE is only used for the key schedule, not the KEM. Hence, the encapsulation is independent of the PSK and only dependent on the long-lived HPKE key. The encryption happens with the key from the HPKE key schedule that includes the PSK.

So I'd suggest to add your explanations about the security guarantees and some basic explanation (like the one above) for how the PSK is used in HPKE (to make it clear where the security properties come from).

comments.body:
If I read this correctly, you use `targeted_message_tbm` as `aad`, which means it is public.
Is this what you intend to do? The content looks like something that shouldn't be "public"
A related question is probably what the attacker model is, in particular is the attacker another group member or from outside the group?

I'm not sure what you mean with 'public' in this context? My understanding is that the AAD is only included in the integrity verification but the actual payload is not included.

The attacker model should be the same as for the core MLS protocol. The base attacker is a network attacker, but you also need to consider what could happen if that attacker has compromised group members.

The way AAD is transferred is outside of the security models. It's attacker controlled, but actual mode of transport is irrelevant.
There's just a lot of stuff in there and I wanted to make sure this is intentional. I  don't think I see anything dangerous in there.

reviews.author: TWal
reviews.body:
Looks overall good, however I think there is no need to derive a second separate secret tree.
We can derive the `message_stream_[I]` from the original secret tree.

As a personal taste, I wouldn't serialize the stream number in ascii as is suggested by `message_stream_[I]`, and instead use the standard big-endian encoding (e.g. in the `context` input of `ExpandWithLabel`).

As noted in a separate comment, `stream_id` is not authenticated by signature of `FramedContentTBS`.
It is probably fine because it is implicitly authenticated as being part of the key derivations to obtain the encryption key, though, but I'm not entirely sure about that (didn't think deeply about it).

comments.body:
```suggestion
Some applications may require more than one application message ratchet. For example, an application may want to send messages with different delivery semantics or different policies. This section describes an extension to MLS which allows MLS clients to send multiple types of messages. Each message type has its own independent key ratchet.
```

Overall I find this introduction a bit vague. I understood that the main motivation was to be able to process the different streams at different paces, i.e. to be able to decrypt latest message of stream A without decrypting all messages of stream B.
It would be great if this paragraph transmitted this intuition.
"application may encode their different message types within `FramedContent.application_data`"?

Note that `stream_id` isn't authenticated in the message signature (unlike `wire_format` which is present in `FramedContentTBS`).
It might not be a problem since it is included in the key schedule, but I'm not sure about that.
What is the LeafNode extension?

I agree with TWal. A slightly less vague example would help a lot in the intro.

"For example, one message stream might be used for frequent bulk-priority messages, while another is used for infrequent urgent notifications. This would allow a client after a network outage to decrypt the urgent stream immediately while still decrypting bulk-priority messages."

What happens with the handshake messages is still not clear though. If there are lots of adds and joins in the group, the client will still need to process all of the commits and all the ratchets will need to change anyway right?

pulls.title: Safe extensions
pulls.author: kkohbrok
pulls.body:
This PR is joint work with @mulmarta, @raphaelrobert and @psyoptix. It includes a brief section on general guidance, as well as the “safe extension API”.

(The following text was also sent to the MLS WG mailing list.)

The extension developer guidance section gives a brief overview over the different places in which MLS is extensible (GroupInfo, GroupContext, etc.) and what properties MLS can provide for extensions in each of those places. There is nothing that can’t be gleaned from the MLS specification or the architecture doc, but it might be a helpful summary for extension designers.

The main contribution of the PR is the safe extension API. The MLS specification doesn’t place any restrictions on what extensions can and can’t do, which means that in particular extensions can invalidate any and all of the security guarantees MLS and other extensions provide. While in some cases it makes sense for an extension to interfere with the main protocol mechanics, for the majority of extensions controlled access to a subset of the functionalities provided by MLS should be sufficient. The safe extensions API describes an interface that extensions can use to make use of functionalities like exporters, PSK injection, public key encryption, signatures, etc. without invalidating the privacy, authenticity and agreement properties of MLS. Similarly, extensions that only use this API do not interfere with any other extensions which only use this API. We call extensions that only use this API “safe extensions”.

For the most part, this is achieved through proper domain separation both between extensions and the MLS protocol, as well as between extensions.

As part of the API, the PR defines generic proposals, wire formats and credentials that can be safely used by extension developers. These definitions also mean that an extension developer won’t have to request IANA code points for any additional structs besides the extension itself.

The PR also provides two examples of safe extensions: The first example is a simple RBAC extension that keeps state externally. Note that there are many ways to implement RBAC and this is just an example (which will be modified in a later PR, see below). The second example is the already existing Targeted Messages extension, which we have adapted to use the safe extension API.

Finally, we want to note that this PR is only step one. In the next step, we want to provide a safe way of reading and writing to (the state of) GroupContext extensions beyond a group context extension proposal. We felt that the PR had already gotten quite big and we wanted to put it up for discussion in time for a fresh draft of the extension doc before IETF 118.

comments.author: TWal
comments.body:
It's a good idea -- it would be a shame if an extension reduced the security of MLS!

I only skimmed through it, but I do have a few remarks.

To ensure disambiguation between signatures / HPKE encryptions / exported secrets, we created a IANA registry for their labels, to ensure an extension doesn't reuse a label defined in MLS, or defined in another extension.
The safe extension API do use these labels (and update the IANA registry) to define new "safe" versions of these functions, but then I think we then need another IANA registry to ensure two extensions don't use the same label e.g. for `SafeSignWithLabel` (same for other "safe" functions).

And a small nit, `VerifyWithLabel` / `SignWithLabel` are always used with a label consisting of the signature input type name (here, `LabeledExtensionContent`), although here it's used with the labels `ExtensionsDataTBS` and `ExtensionDataTBS` (which is a bug by the way!)

comments.author: psyoptix
comments.body:
yup, domain separation between extensions is critical to achieve the Safe API's goals. the API does this using just the (IANA registered)  Extension Type. A safe extension must register its own Extension Type unique among all other safe extensions with IANA. That already gives us a unique number we can extend to domain separate all labels.

For example, for a safe extension to use HPKE the safe API enforces that the HPKE label is `LabeledExtensionContent` which contains the `ExtensionContent` which in turn has an `ExtensionType` field. As that value is different for each safe extension the full HPKE labels for different extensions is always distinct.

The same idea is used for all other extension defined labels in the safe API which means the only value a new extension must register with IANA is its Extension Type.

Thanks for pointing this out! I've changed the labels accordingly.

pulls.author: kkohbrok
pulls.body: This PR is joint work with @psyoptix, @mulmarta and @raphaelrobert.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Hi, @kkohbrok @psyoptix @mulmarta I realize that this has been approved, however I think it conflates three things:
- making GroupContext items that are hidden from non-members. This should be encrypted somehow rather than hashed. Hashing just pushes the problem of getting the context somewhere else
- the ability to patch the GroupContext is a problem we are also trying to solve with the (App)Sync proposal. Again, we don't want a hash here.
- incorporating GroupState for which the master copy of this data is elsewhere, but we want to have agreement on it. This is a great use of a hash.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
I'm not sure I understand what you're suggesting here. A couple of points:

- ExtensionState allows (safe) extensions to safely anchor state in the group context. As such it's a "lower-level" mechanism than AppSync as it's meant to be used by extensions (such as AppSync) rather than an application running on top of MLS. 
- ExtensionState doesn't preclude extensions from storing encrypted data. I agree that hashing isn't necessarily the best way to limit visibility, mostly because the hash might leak data to the DS. I'd be okay with removing that sentence. However, as you point out using ExtensionState to anchor data in hash form is still useful.
- ExtensionState doesn't prescribe how individual extensions should patch their data. That's by design, as we assume that the extension will handle that in some other way, for example, via extension-defined proposals. So there's no redundancy with what AppSync is trying to do.

pulls.title: Clarify how capabilities negotiation works in Safe Extensions framework.
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
Note: this diff is easier to read when viewed as diffs for its separate commits. The first Commit is just a plain move of one section.

- Moved the text in "Storing State in Extensions" earlier and renamed
- describe the original "ExtensionTypes" as "Core struct extensions"
- added a section on capabilities handling and negotiation
- instruct IANA to add a "Safe" column to "MLS Extension Types"
- instruct IANA that a safe extension can have N/A in the Message(s) column.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> Is there a reason you want the extension WireFormat, Proposal, etc. to be part of the safe extension API? 

Yes! Safe WireFormats, Safe Proposals, and Safe Credentials share the `mls-extension_message`, `extension*proposal`, and `extension_credential` types respectively;  all of these MUST use the ExtensionContent struct; and all of them use the capabilities negotiation I described. The whole reason I wrote this PR was because it was simply not possible to write rules for safe extension of one these types without stepping into rules that should be defined in the framework.

>Our thinking was to keep it separate, because *it* [my emphasis] might also be useful for non-safe extensions.

I'm not sure what the *it* is. RFC9420 already says what you need to do for non-safe extensions of these types. If the creator of a non-safe extension wants to reuse some structs defined the Safe Extensions framework, I don't see any problem with this, but they absolutely MUST NOT use the IANA registered `mls-extension_message`, `extension*proposal`, and `extension_credential` types.  If you wanted to make it easier to find/reference the `ExtensionState` struct for example, I would suggest we get this PR merged and then we can have a clean PR proposing the move. Otherwise the conflicts get ugly and the PR is harder to review.

Safe Extensions has two main benefits:

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> In a scenario where the MLS implementation doesn't know the extension, i.e. it's not in the capabilities then why wouldn't the application show proposals, etc. to the application regardless whether the extension is safe or not? If the implementation of the unknown extension can't be delegated to the application, the extension really should have been in the required capabilities.

Let's take the example of an AssociatedParties "feature". It has:
- one GroupContext
- 3 Proposals (adding, removing, and updating this GC)
- A label for a new secret

The "feature" has a single ExtensionType say it is type 0xBEEF. The proposals are `extension_proposal`, `extension_path_proposal`, and `extension_path_proposal` types respectively. After each of these would be the ExtensionType 0xBEEF and then inside the extension_path_proposal, a selector in the TLS struct to select between the remove and update variants of the struct.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body: Looking at it more closely, maybe I don't understand what you're getting at. I understand the AP extension example and that's indeed how the mechanism is intended, but why can't we use the same mechanism (i.e. bundle multiple proposals, WireFormats, etc. behind a single extension type) with a non-safe extension?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> Looking at it more closely, maybe I don't understand what you're getting at. I understand the AP extension example and that's indeed how the mechanism is intended, but why can't we use the same mechanism (i.e. bundle multiple proposals, WireFormats, etc. behind a single extension type) with a non-safe extension?

I think we should be making it clear and easy to make safe extensions. The creator of a non-safe extension *could* use the same or similar mechanism, but we can't be prescriptive about what non-safe extension can and can't do. They don't *HAVE TO*. However for safe extensions we can say, they have to do a specific thing. That's why I don't particularly care to spend a lot of energy on considerations for non-safe extensions. It's not that I don't want non-safe extensions to do better, it's that they are free to ignore anything we do say now (the horse is already out of the barn).

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
Fair enough, then I'm okay with this PR. 

I don't think, however, that just because an extension is safe, it can be safely ignored by both client and application. For example, if a client receives a commit with an extension proposal from a safe extension where the proposal is invalid according to the extension's semantics. A client that is knows the extension will consider the commit invalid. A client that doesn't will consider the commit invalid.

This has caused us to find many problems earlier than we otherwise would have by making the author of an extension or component document where they plan to use it.
that's just following how mls-extensions specified these things in all former versions. happy to change across in a future PR.

On further thought, I affirmatively think that we should **not** be this prescriptive.  It strongly implies that the MLS stack should enforce these rules, and that doesn't make sense. Unlike extensions, which the MLS stack has to support, the MLS stack is completely ignorant of the meaning of app components.  (Indeed, that's why there's so much private use space.)
Comments crossed in the ether :)  Maybe we can just be clear that the MLS stack will not enforce these, so the application needs to be prepared for components to show up in unexpected places.

```suggestion

The restrictions noted in the "Where" column are to be enforced by the
application.  MLS implementations MUST NOT impose restrictions on where
component IDs are used in which parts of MLS, unless specifically directed to by
the application.
```

```suggestion
| 0x0000 0000   | RESERVED                 | N/A   | - | RFCXXXX |
| 0x0000 0001   | app_components           | LN,GC | Y | RFCXXXX |
| 0x0000 0002   | safe_aad                 | LN,GC | Y | RFCXXXX |
| 0x0000 0003   | content_media_types      | LN,GC | Y | RFCXXXX |
| 0x0000 0004   | last_resort_key_package  | KP    | Y | RFCXXXX |
| 0x0000 0005   | app_ack                  | AE    | Y | RFCXXXX |
```

```suggestion

Initial Contents:
```

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
On the process: I can understand the motivation for this, but I don't think it should be folded into this document at this late stage.

On the merits: 

This seems more like a "ScootOver" proposal than "Consolidate", since it only really consolidates anything if the rightmost person does it.  

Given how MLS suppresses unnecessary intermediate nodes, it seems like there's probably a more complete algorithm to identify the smallest tree that can represent all of the non-blank nodes in a given tree.  For example:

```
BEFORE:
              X
              |
        .-----+-----.
       /             \
      _               _
      |               |
    .-+-.           .-+-.
   /     \         /     \
  _       _       _       _
 / \     / \     / \     / \
A   _   _   _   _   _   _   H

AFTER:
  X
 / \
A   H
```

```
BEFORE:
              X
              |
        .-----+-----.
       /             \
      _               Y
      |               |
    .-+-.           .-+-.
   /     \         /     \
  _       _       _       _
 / \     / \     / \     / \
A   _   _   _   E   _   _   H

AFTER:
      X
      |
    .-+-.
   /     \
  _       Y
 / \     / \
A   _   E   H
```

It seems like that algorithm could be entirely deterministic, roughly:

* Remove the blank nodes from the tree, resulting in an unbalanced binary tree
* The depth of the new tree is the depth of the unbalanced tree
* Place the leaf nodes at the leaves of a tree of that depth
* ... as far left as possible, while still allowing for the intermediate nodes to be placed above them.

So you could just have it be done after all other modifications to the tree are done, and all members would do it consistently.

In fact, you don't really need a proposal at all -- just an extension that says to always do this at the end of Commit processing, just like you always truncate after a Remove.

But it's not clear what resource you're actually saving here.  While this is fun math, blank nodes in the tree do not take up much more space either in memory or on the wire, and they don't cause any additional cryptographic operations to be done.

All of which underscores that there's more complexity here than we should be adding at this stage.  Let's make a fresh draft.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body:
I think this paper here has analyzed this more formally (Section 3.4 in particular): https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/746

~~I'm not concerned with local memory or even necessarily compute. Getting rid of blanks makes shorter paths and fewer ciphertexts, which reduce commit size especially in the PQ setting. I'll try to make that clearer in the intro.~~

I agree this should probably be an extension, as we want it to happen with every commit. But then the question is whether each commit is trying to optimize for the result of that particular operation, or whether the idea is to converge towards an optimal solution eventually. I'd be in favour of the latter. After all group members should commit regularly to achieve PCS. In the "scoot over" case there's not much more to be added in terms of complexity.

EDIT: It turns out I had misremembered how efficiently blanks are handled in the tree. It turns out that moving members to the left of the tree doesn't make as much of a difference as I thought.

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body:
I think there are a few things to consider here:

a) It is a last-minute addition to the document. For that to be acceptable, we need to be sure about the following:
 - It solves a real problem (this is being debated)
 - It is sound and not terribly complex to implement (that's probably the case)
 - There's a good reason not to do it in a new draft (that reason is yet to be clearly stated)

b) @bifurcation Your proposed solution sounds interesting as well. Given its complexity, it's likely out of scope for mls-extensions. I also think it wouldn't work with the existing tree hash algorithm, thus requiring even more changes.

With that in mind, we could try to give it another whirl and see if the conditions for relevance can be met. The next step should also be to discuss this on list.

My two cents on it is that it's probably good hygiene to move committers to the left. I think it comes at no cost (on average), and – on the contrary – will make for tidier trees. Ideally, running some (MC) simulations would show whether we can save on KEM operations.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Hi,
The idea of this Proposal (which I think of as the "scootch" Proposal) doesn't seem that hard to implement, but the application of it seems limited to groups where you had a very large number of members and now you have just a fraction. Otherwise I don't see a lot of value. We don't have consensus that this is actually a problem, let alone that we need a solution to it and that it needs to be in the mls-extensions draft.
Thanks, -r

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Privacy question:
Do we consider how long you have been in a group  or how often you commit to be privacy sensitive?
If the epoch is fairly large, new joiners will fill in blank nodes and so your leaf index is pretty random. With this proposal it would be much more likely a long-lived member or a frequent committer is to the left in the tree. Do we care?

comments.author: raphaelrobert
comments.body:
> Privacy question: Do we consider how long you have been in a group or how often you commit to be privacy sensitive? If the epoch is fairly large, new joiners will fill in blank nodes and so your leaf index is pretty random. With this proposal it would be much more likely a long-lived member or a frequent committer is to the left in the tree. Do we care?

In vanilla MLS we have a similar issue: When groups are relatively static, you can infer who joined in what order. I don't think this proposal would introduce anything worse. 
I also don't think frequent committers would be easily identifiable with this proposal. The rule is to jump into the leftmost free leaf, which might very well be on the right side of the tree.

comments.author: kkohbrok
comments.body: I'm closing this for now as the performance benefit is less pronounced as I had originally thought. As Raphael mentioned, an MC simulation would be nice to see how big the benefit would be in the end, but I don't have the capacity right now.

reviews.author: kkohbrok
reviews.body: Looks good to me with three suggestions.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The `ComponentData` within the `app_data_dictionary` and the use of `SafeAAD` within messages can be used to provide cross-layer support for applications that use MLS but also influence one or more other protocol layers. Application components can store group configurations within the `ComponentData` struct and use the `SafeAAD` struct to communicate between one another. Furthermore, additional capabilities and attributes outside the group-agreed configuration can also be conveyed through the `app_data_dictionary` extension in the `LeafNode` or `KeyPackage`. This section provides some examples of cross-layer support functionalities that may be achieved through the `app_data_dictionary` usage.
```

```suggestion
An ALPA component could be implemented as follows: A group's required application-layer protocols are listed in the `data` vector of the `ComponentData` struct within the `app_data_dictionary` in the `GroupContext`. When a new member is being added to the group, their `KeyPackage` must contain at least the required application protocols of the group. This list is either equal to or a superset of the aforementioned list in the `GroupContext`. A member's full list of supported application protocols is recorded in that member's `app_data_dictionary` in their `LeafNode` `Capabilities` struct.
```

Saying a non-application layer system is a bit contradictory. We should either move away from the term "application" or be more specific by what we mean by non-application layer system. Maybe explain that "application" in "non-application layer systems" refers to the OSI definition of the term?

```suggestion
non-application layer systems. Specifically, this refers to the OSI definition of applications that categorizes them according to their specific function within the communications stack. 
```
